revised_title: Bacteria Survival and Photogenic Properties at Extreme Temperatures
tldr: This study investigates the effects of extremely low temperatures on bacteria, specifically the temperature of liquid air. The experiments found that bacteria, including the highly resistant spores of B. anthracis, could survive exposure to -182°C to -190°C for twenty hours without any impairment of their vitality. Additionally, photogenic bacteria maintained their luminous properties after being cooled and then thawed. The study also demonstrated that bacteria can survive in liquefied laboratory air at -210°C.
